instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKLT_PWM: What is BKLT_PWM? BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKLT_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight boost
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had some liquid damage. I have replaced a few components and now have normal behavior (fan-spin, image, proper rails, etc). Only issue is that backlight starts out at about 25V and slowly drops down to the non-boosted voltage as I measure it. I've tried multiple screens, and I replaced <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. I confirmed that the feedback line has continuity from Pin 5 on <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> to the other side of the board near <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>. Any thoughts? Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight boost
threads.message:
"Pin 5 on <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> to the other side of the board near <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>"
Not near; do you have contact with p?n K of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>?

What happen with <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM?
Did you try PRAM reset?
Did you try known good LCD assembly?

Check all traces, resistors and resolder all them (around <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>); pay atention to <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and the 6 return resistors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight boost
threads.message: Sorry, yes. I have continuity between pin 5 on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and the boost side of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>. <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> is 2.85, <SIGNAL>BKL_PWN</SIGNAL> is 0.00 (both values are when screen is attached). All resistors measure within spec and traces look good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight boost
threads.message: I've also tried PRAM zap and multiple known-good LCD assemblies

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight boost
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>BKL_PWN</SIGNAL> is 0.00 "
Not normal at all, check <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR>.
If good, remove it and run a wire from <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR>.
Test if backlight appears.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight boost
threads.message:
yes, that gives us backlight with the jumper in place. <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> tests fine... OK so what does this tell us? <SIGNAL>BKL_PWN</SIGNAL> is the source of the problem? Which means I have a CPU issue? I'm assuming I can't leave this jumper in place full time...

FWIW with <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> removed <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> measures 2.1M ohms to ground (no short), and I get about 2.4v on that line for a split second during POST. But then it quickly drops to 1.4v and then 0.0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight boost
threads.message: I just read the sticky on this topic, sorry for not finding it sooner. I see now why you suggested a PRAM zap...to reset what might have been a fully lowered brightness setting. So I guess I could leave the jumper in place if the owner approves the loss of brightness control. I am curious where the issue with <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> actually lies, at least now I can dig a bit more on my own. Thanks SO MUCH for your guidance!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight boost
threads.message:
Try again 2-3 PRAM resets.
Then put back <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and test.
Be sure to have good solders on its pins!
